comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Weddigen "On 22 September 1914, while patrolling in the region of the southern North Sea known to the British as the "Broad Fourteens", U-9 intercepted the three warships of the Seventh Cruiser Squadron, also known as the Live Bait Squadron. Weddigen fired off all six of his torpedoes, reloaded while submerged, and in less than an hour sank the three British armoured cruisers HMS Aboukir, HMS Hogue and HMS Cressy. Sixty two officers and 1,397 men were killed, only 837 survived." But Weddigen's career was soon cut short. The following March HMS Dreadnought cut the U-Boat he was commanding, U29, in two. There were no survivors.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A silent movie was made in 1927 about the U-9 and Weddigen www.imdb.com/title/tt0018521/ www.firstworldwar.com/bio/weddigen.htm confirms that Weddigen is third from left in the seated row. submarine.50megs.com/ottow.html includes another copy of this picture (perhaps a postcard) with the caption "Unsere Helden", "Our Heroes." Weddigen wrote his own account of the incident. A translation is at www.gwpda.org/1914/u-9.html and lots more photos and another copy of his account are at angloboerwarmuseum.com/Boer13_plates2_u9.html

comment._content: Sad story my friend, god bless you, lovely photo of some great men
